Mirage Kitchen Store

Mirage Kitchen Store is an e-commerce web app I built from scratch using React, Redux, and Firebase. It required a lot of planning and heavy lifting, including maintaining a universal cart and storing favorite and cart items for users in Firestore database.

Live

View Site

TYPE

Side Project

STACK

Stripe

Netlify

Web Stack and Explanation

React, Redux, Firebase, and Netlify made the most sense in this application. I find Redux more efficient than the Context API when managing the app’s complex state. While I can maintain the whole state in one place with Redux, I would have to make separate files for the user, shop categories, and shop items contexts to make it more maintainable and scalable with the Context API.

Furthermore, Firebase made it easy for the client to edit and add new items without coding.

Netlify made it straightforward to deploy the app and integrate Stripe’s serverless functions to manage user payments.

Problems and Thought Process

Before I started to code out the project, I planned extensively and thought I had everything figured out. Nevertheless, I had many bumps along the way. I had to expand some of the states many times. But thanks to Redux, everything was less painful.

I tried my best to ensure component reusability and used props where I didn’t need the state to be globally available. Tailwind CSS also made it easy to add and modify styles and see immediate changes without having a separate CSS file.

Lessons Learned

As my first big React project, I have learned a ton of new things. The most important ones are the need for a good code organization and structure, Git management, Redux, and problem solving skills.
